etymologies: late Middle English (as a noun denoting a formal justification): from French apologétique or late Latin apologeticus, from Greek apologētikos, from apologeisthei ‘speak in one's own defense’, from apologia (see apology). The current sense dates from the mid 19th century

definitions: regretfully acknowledging or excusing an offense or failure

examples.text: she was very apologetic about the whole incident

shortDefinitions: regretfully acknowledging or excusing offense or failure

definitions: of the nature of a formal defense or justification of something such as a theory or religious doctrine

examples.text: the apologetic proposition that production for profit is the same thing as production for need

shortDefinitions: of nature of formal defense or justification of something
